title: OpenTAD: A Unified Framework and Comprehensive Study of Temporal Action Detection
author: Shuming Liu (King Abdullah University of Science and Technology), Chen Zhao (King Abdullah University of Science and Technology), Fatimah Zohra (King Abdullah University of Science and Technology), Mattia Soldan (King Abdullah University of Science and Technology), Alejandro Pardo (King Abdullah University of Science and Technology), Mengmeng Xu (King Abdullah University of Science and Technology), Lama Alssum (King Abdullah University of Science and Technology), ... , Bernard Ghanem (King Abdullah University of Science and Technology)
background: Temporal action detection involves identifying and pinpointing the timing of human actions within video content, which represents a challenging problem in video understanding.
contribution: OpenTAD introduces a modular framework that consolidates various temporal action detection methods and datasets, enabling extensive performance evaluation and comparison.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Prior methods suffer from inconsistencies due to the lack of standardized frameworks, making comparisons challenging.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work rectifies this by providing a unified codebase to facilitate fair comparisons and analyze different architectural components.

key_innovation: The framework's modular design allows easy integration of various detection methods, datasets, and evaluation protocols while promoting reproducibility.
real_world_impact: OpenTAD has the potential to accelerate advancements in temporal action detection by providing researchers with reliable tools and resources, thereby fostering innovation in video understanding applications.
limitations: No explicit limitations are mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.temporal action detection: **Temporal action detection** refers to the computer vision task of locating and labeling actions occurring over time in video sequences.
new_terms.modular design: **Modular design** allows different components of a system to be developed, tested, and upgraded independently of one another.

open_sourcing: The code and models are available at https://github.com/sming256/OpenTAD
